title: Prediabetes and Your Gut Health

content: Prediabetes affects nearly 98 million people in the U.S. ages 18 and older, which amounts to 38% of the population, according to the CDC. In prediabetes, blood glucose levels (BGL) are higher than normal but not high enough to qualify for type 2 diabetes. However, most cases of type 2 diabetes are usually diagnosed after months or years of having prediabetes.

There’s nothing “pre” about prediabetes, which is caused by cells’ resistance to insulin. Insulin binds to cells and allows glucose to enter, lowering BGL. In addition to prediabetes and type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance is linked to inflammation and the buildup of plaque in blood vessels that can block blood flow to the heart, brain, and other parts of the body. Prediabetes can also alter gut health in ways you can and cannot feel.

The gut is home to trillions of microbes, nearly all of which benefit your health. Gut bacteria produce several types of compounds, including short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), such as butyrate. People who don’t process insulin properly have lower levels of a type of bacteria that produces butyrate.

content: Short-chain fatty acids are important for gut health, which in turn affects your overall well-being. They provide energy for gut cells, reduce the growth of bad bacteria that can make you sick, help reduce inflammation, and support the gut barrier.

When SCFA production is limited, it affects the strength of the gut wall. A weak wall allows a compound called lipopolysaccharides to leak into the blood and circulate around. Lipopolysaccharides are linked to inflammation that increases insulin resistance and makes it harder to control BGL.

People with prediabetes have a lower gut diversity, meaning fewer types of beneficial bacteria live in their gut. A diverse gut is linked to a lower risk for gut health issues, including inflammation and obesity which contribute to higher BGL and increase the risk for developing type 2 diabetes.

Elevated BGL can harm nerves and result in gastroparesis, which prevents your stomach from emptying properly. In gastroparesis, nerve damage in the stomach slows or stops digestion and causes pain and bloating. Nerve damage can also disrupt other normal gut functions, resulting in constipation or diarrhea.

sections.heading: Reduce Prediabetes and Improve Gut Health
content: It’s possible to reverse high BGL and improve gut health at the same time with diet and exercise.  Your doctor may also prescribe medication to help reduce BGL.

Eat a balanced diet. Many people with prediabetes are overweight or have obesity. Even small changes in weight go a long way to improving BGL and helping your gut. An eating plan that includes the right amount of calories from carbohydrates, fat, and protein is essential for weight control. If you don’t know how to plan a balanced diet, work with a registered dietitian nutritionist (RDN).

Include at least 25 grams of fiber daily. Beneficial bacteria use dietary fiber as food to produce SCFA and other beneficial compounds.  A diet rich in fiber also slows the rise in BGL, which could help reduce insulin resistance.

Limit added sugar and refined grains. Sweet foods and drinks rich in added sugar and refined grains, such as white bread, pretzels, and chips, make prediabetes worse. The body quickly breaks down sugars and refined grains to glucose and elevates glucose levels in the blood. A steady diet of sugar and refined grains can worsen insulin resistance.

sections.heading: Exercise on a regular basis.
content: Physical activity reduces blood glucose levels and increases blood flow to the gut to keep it working properly. Aim for 150 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise, such as brisk walking, and two sessions of strength training weekly.
